title: Invalid merkle root leads to skip duplicated bad block for a block that is actually valid.

body: This [post](https://github.com/ethereum/go-ethereum/issues/21825#issuecomment-904671062) on https://github.com/ethereum/go-ethereum/issues/21825 looks to be another person that hit this same problem:

I'm having a similar problem which started after upgrading to v1.10.8-stable. I'm not saying it's the cause, just a fact. The problem was corrected has not occurred after I rebooted this morning.

System Info:
```
$ inxi -Fxz
System:    Kernel: 5.11.0-27-generic x86_64 bits: 64 compiler: N/A Console: tty 0 Distro: Ubuntu 20.04.3 LTS (Focal Fossa) 
Machine:   Type: Mini-pc System: Intel Client Systems product: NUC8i5BEH v: J72747-308 serial: <filter> 
           Mobo: Intel model: NUC8BEB v: J72692-310 serial: <filter> UEFI: Intel v: BECFL357.86A.0081.2020.0504.1834 
           date: 05/04/2020 
CPU:       Topology: Quad Core model: Intel Core i5-8259U bits: 64 type: MT MCP arch: Kaby Lake rev: A L2 cache: 6144 KiB 
           flags: avx avx2 lm nx pae sse sse2 sse3 sse4_1 sse4_2 ssse3 vmx bogomips: 36799 
           Speed: 1892 MHz min/max: 400/3800 MHz Core speeds (MHz): 1: 1892 2: 2066 3: 2900 4: 1761 5: 1840 6: 1656 7: 1991 
           8: 1895 
```
This is on goerli/prater testnet and upgraded to v1.10.8 on Aug 28:
```
$ rg 'instance=' eth1.service.logs 
316971:Aug 05 11:02:28 ethel geth[1359]: INFO [08-05|11:02:28.074] Starting peer-to-peer node               instance=Geth/v1.10.6-stable-576681f2/linux-amd64/go1.16.4
465371:Aug 13 09:31:12 ethel geth[1404]: INFO [08-13|09:31:12.768] Starting peer-to-peer node               instance=Geth/v1.10.7-stable-12f0ff40/linux-amd64/go1.16.4
...
673365:Aug 23 14:36:42 ethel geth[1567]: INFO [08-23|14:36:42.842] Starting peer-to-peer node               instance=Geth/v1.10.7-stable-12f0ff40/linux-amd64/go1.16.4
773234:Aug 28 15:06:02 ethel geth[1550]: INFO [08-28|15:06:02.016] Starting peer-to-peer node               instance=Geth/v1.10.8-stable-26675454/linux-amd64/go1.16.4
775508:Aug 28 18:40:53 ethel geth[1531]: INFO [08-28|18:40:53.050] Starting peer-to-peer node               instance=Geth/v1.10.8-stable-26675454/linux-amd64/go1.16.4
775629:Aug 28 18:44:21 ethel geth[1528]: INFO [08-28|18:44:21.757] Starting peer-to-peer node               instance=Geth/v1.10.8-stable-26675454/linux-amd64/go1.16.4
1637404:Sep 03 09:55:34 ethel geth[172207]: INFO [09-03|09:55:34.015] Starting peer-to-peer node               instance=Geth/v1.10.8-stable-26675454/linux-amd64/go1.16.4
1645028:Sep 03 10:13:24 ethel geth[1537]: INFO [09-03|10:13:24.446] Starting peer-to-peer node               instance=Geth/v1.10.8-stable-26675454/linux-amd64/go1.16.4```
```
I searched my logs and I have nearly 3500 "Error: invalid merkle .." messages:
```
wink@3900x:~/eth2-stuff/ethel
$ rg 'invalid mer' eth1.service.logs > eth1.service.invalid-merkle.logs 
wink@3900x:~/eth2-stuff/ethel
$ wc -l < eth1.service.invalid-merkle.logs 
3489
```
Here is the first and last in eth1.service.invalid-merkle.logs:
```
wink@3900x:~/eth2-stuff/ethel
$ head -n 1 eth1.service.invalid-merkle.logs 
Sep 01 19:46:30 ethel geth[1528]: Error: invalid merkle root (remote: ddfe68e7ce1d52063379e661b3037ce4a9e37bbc11db741841c26583f42ac5e2 local: ea6545dda3b7bb7718aed7fcd5922d71fa3056fe7d795091dea012d578bef588)
wink@3900x:~/eth2-stuff/ethel
$ tail -n 1 eth1.service.invalid-merkle.logs 
Sep 03 10:11:37 ethel geth[172207]: Error: invalid merkle root (remote: a9d4fd114f73d6d64edc50e1c4e0ccb9b2455f685d0fdad7208a07509b8b4e71 local: d540511735d0e3dbf0e2afbbed9384de138012b74f9070729265a1be54442f5a)
wink@3900x:~/eth2-stuff/ethel
```
And here is the first from the full logs:
```
Sep 01 19:46:26 ethel geth[1528]: INFO [09-01|19:46:26.500] Imported new chain segment               blocks=1  txs=5   mgas=0.761  elapsed=25.487ms    mgasps=29.868    number=5,425,306 hash=81ba07..86b349 dirty=255.84MiB

And here is the last one just before I rebooted:
```
Sep 03 10:11:37 ethel geth[172207]:          428: cumulative: 29807365 gas: 24182 contract: 0x0000000000000000000000000000000000000000 status: 0 tx: 0x3ceaf2096477ea16cf227cb726481db4583883235a73c5c3820cc86fa53b6d71 logs: [] bloom:  state:

Sep 03 10:12:51 ethel systemd[1]: eth1.service: Main process exited, code=exited, status=1/FAILURE
Sep 03 10:12:51 ethel systemd[1]: eth1.service: Failed with result 'exit-code'.
Sep 03 10:12:51 ethel systemd[1]: Stopped geth eth1 service.
-- Reboot --
Sep 03 10:13:23 ethel systemd[1]: Started geth eth1 service.
Sep 03 10:13:24 ethel geth[1537]: INFO [09-03|10:13:24.066] Starting pprof server                    addr=http://127.0.0.1:6060/debug/pprof
Sep 03 10:13:24 ethel geth[1537]: INFO [09-03|10:13:24.067] Starting Geth on Grli testnet...
Sep 03 10:13:24 ethel geth[1537]: INFO [09-03|10:13:24.067] Enabling metrics collection
Sep 03 10:13:24 ethel geth[1537]: INFO [09-03|10:13:24.070] Maximum peer count                       ETH=50 LES=0 total=50
```
[Here is a link to the 900M of logs](https://drive.google.com/file/d/1LeUKb4iPlWCOuZaEY5sUm8AeeqLTk4-c/view?usp=sharing) that span from 2021-07-19 to 2021-09-03. If you only want a subset or you'd like let me upload them elsewhere I can.
Yes, restarting geth seems to clear the issue and allow it to continue syncing. So it seems to be a caching related problem.

In my case I wasn't syncing it had already been sync'd and was running "fine" since July. But on the reboot it said "Block synchronisation started": 
```

```
Note; in my case it took a full reboot, just doing a `sudo systemctl restart eth1.service` **did not** do the trick.
In the cases I have seen it had also not been syncing prior to getting into the stuck state, however restarting geth did get things going again.
Looks like this issue was also reported here: https://github.com/ethereum/go-ethereum/issues/23442

In our case, nodes were previously running 1.10.6. We have seen an increase in this issue occurring after upgrading from 1.10.6 to 1.10.8. Looking over the commits between those two releases that could have impacted state related to caching, I see [this change](https://github.com/ethereum/go-ethereum/pull/23299/files) #23299, that may or may not be related.
Looks like another possible duplicate issue of this was opened: https://github.com/ethereum/go-ethereum/issues/23546

@jsolman have you solved this problem
I hit this issue some days ago, but can't reproduce it now.
I am review codes which may result into this,
Do you have some clue

geth 1.10.6 also had a similar issue trying to resync following the Ropsten fork issue

Provided details here:
https://github.com/ethereum/go-ethereum/issues/23546#issuecomment-919025126

I also notice your tx's are reverse ordered compared to [etherscan](https://etherscan.io/txs?block=13107518) or does etherscan show tx's in reverse order?

@SanJue The problem still persists. One theory is that something is going wrong with the acceleration snapshot support related to in memory data structures, since the problem is resolved by restarting geth.

> @SanJue The problem still persists. One theory is that something is going wrong with the acceleration snapshot support related to in memory data structures, since the problem is resolved by restarting geth.

yeah, may be cache or some memory data structures. Thank you!

I think this issue is a bit of several things mixed up. 
```
INFO [08-30|13:52:03.478] Skip duplicated bad block                number=13,124,881 hash=082281..3510d2
```
This particular output is not important, i.e: it does not signify "I won't process this block because I've already seen it, and it's bad". It only means "When persisting this 'badblock' to db, I found that it already is stored, so I won't store it again". So it just means that geth processed a block, found it bad, and tried to store it. 

So the problem is the 
```
Error: invalid merkle root (remote: c3fa9eba68fbc0cb7cd219714014ae6e3d1bf609dcc797643480ec22b7ca96d0 local: f8dbee2c1a3bb252ea7d5147633ca5297ec535d2926ceeed20c0381b579522df)
```
These can have different causes. For @winksaville , I think the database is corrupt. 
```
Sep 03 10:12:51 ethel geth[172207]: CRIT [09-03|10:12:51.923] Failed to store snapshot generator       err="leveldb/table: corruption on data-block (pos=1448842): checksum mismatch, want=0xc3666b0a got=0xcc5edf8d [file=080810.ldb]"
```
-- `"leveldb/table: corruption on data-block (pos=1448842): checksum mismatch, want=0xc3666b0a got=0xcc5edf8d [file=080810.ldb]"`. This means that an _underlying_ error in leveldb has occurred. This indicates that disk corruption has occurred. I'd recommend doing a disk fault check. 

Furthermore, for @winksaville , we have this: 
```
1537]: WARN [09-03|10:13:24.446] Unclean shutdown detected                booted=2021-08-13T11:18:12-0700 age=2w6d22h
Sep 03 10:13:24 ethel geth[1537]: WARN [09-03|10:13:24.446] Unclean shutdown detected                booted=2021-08-13T16:50:43-0700 age=2w6d17h
Sep 03 10:13:24 ethel geth[1537]: WARN [09-03|10:13:24.446] Unclean shutdown detected                booted=2021-08-23T14:28:54-0700 age=1w3d19h
Sep 03 10:13:24 ethel geth[1537]: WARN [09-03|10:13:24.446] Unclean shutdown detected                booted=2021-09-03T09:55:34-0700 age=17m50s
```
It appears that the process is run as a daemon. When geth is shut down, the operator should give it ample time to store the caches to disk --- up to a couple of minutes is recommended. Not doing so may cause issues (but it should not be the cause for the leveldb corruptions). 

If we instead focus on the original report, the odd thing is this: 

> Note that the node will continue syncing and stop having the issue by just restarting geth, so it seems there is some sort of cache issue.

And yes, if this were just a "the trie data is inconsistent", then it is very odd that it manages to import a block after a restart. @jsolman Do you have the logs for this case: 

1. A "bad block" being reported, then, 
2. Shutting down, restarting, and successfully importing the block
 
I'd be curious to take a look at what those logs say. For example, I'm curious of whether the snapshots are in use during the second run. Otherwise, it may be that the snapshot data is corrupt, and the restart then flips it back to run in trie-only mode. If that is the case, then we could run a verification on snap versus trie to verify it.

I have also found the same issue after updating geth from 1.10.6 to 1.10.8. 

At that time, `geth` was full syncing blocks of 2 days ago, and could not get through when 'BAD BLOCK' came up, and continued to sync the same 'BAD BLOCK' over and over again until a OOM error occurred eventually

And still, after restart the problem disappeared, however I cannot reproduce it now.

the log looks like other people mentioned above
```
ERROR[09-13|11:21:23.324]

I think it might be some concurrent problem, which leads to bad cached data, because not all the nodes had the issue at the same block and become normal after restart.

Yes, let me describe the conditions a bit more
- I was running a full-node of 1.10.6 with state snapshot turned off before
- then I stop the node and updated the binary to 1.10.8 with state snapshot turned on
- after that the node began generating state  snapshot from the beginning while it was fetching blocks from other peers
- then 'BAD BLOCK' came up and the node started to fetch the same block from other peers and still got a 'BAD BLOCK'
- the node became normal after I restarted it
- after that I would get 'BAD BLOCK' occasionally
- when the snapshot was finally built, I cannot reproduce it any more
@zzyalbert that's good info, thanks!

So there appears to be data missing in the trie: 
```
INFO [08-30\|15:09:58.210] Trie missing, state snapshotting paused  root=3a6293..1d18a9 at=63ec11..9da644 accounts=56,208,719 slots=196,424,268 storage=16.66GiB elapsed=1m35.451s eta=271h19m6.871s
```
It's odd that it manages to import the block (and a few more) after a restart.
After verifying v1.10.11 fixes this from including #23635 I will report back here and we can close this.
